events.title: Celebrating five years of J-PAL Middle East and North Africa

collectionItem.title: Celebrating five years of J-PAL Middle East and North Africa

data.title: Celebrating five years of J-PAL Middle East and North Africa
data.seoTitle: Celebrating 5 years of J-PAL MENA
data.description:
The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab Middle East and North Africa (J-PAL MENA) marks its fifth anniversary with a special event hosted at The American University in Cairo (AUC).

Featuring keynote remarks by Professor Abhijit Banerjee, J-PAL co-founder and Nobel laureate, the event brings together policymakers, researchers and implementers to reflect on key milestones, share impact stories and insights from J-PAL initiatives and discuss the future of evidence-based policy-making.

The event will be livestreamed on J-PAL’s YouTube channel.
data.seoMetaDescription: J-PAL MENA marks 5 years of tackling poverty with a special event at the American University in Cairo.

events.title: Mainstreaming climate action in Indian cities

collectionItem.title: Mainstreaming climate action in Indian cities

data.title: Mainstreaming climate action in Indian cities
data.seoTitle: Mainstreaming climate action in Indian cities
data.description:
The Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs are hosting a national convening on mainstreaming climate action in Indian cities on 18-20 June 2025 in Chennai, India.

The three-day event brings together city leaders, technical experts and climate practitioners to advance collaborative, practical approaches to urban climate action.

Many Indian cities, including Ahmedabad, Bengaluru, Chennai, Delhi and Mumbai, are already showing strong climate leadership with inclusive, science-based climate action plans.

As they shift from planning to implementation, the primary challenge now is making climate action part of everyday city systems and embedding it into how cities plan, budget and govern.

Policymakers, practitioners and experts explore how to make climate action a core part of city operations, helping to accelerate the move toward low-carbon, resilient, and inclusive urban futures.

The first two days consist of closed-door technical sessions, which focus on peer learning, problem-solving and strategic planning.

The Jameel C40 Cohort of City Practitioners will be included in those two days, expanding representation to Delhi and Amman.

The final day opens to a wider public audience for discussions on climate budgeting, urban governance and integrated planning, during which the Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs showcase Chennai’s most recent climate change risk assessment (CCRA).

Carried out in partnership with the Urban Management Centre, the CCRA will help shape the next phase of the Labs' efforts, marking a move from assessment to concrete, climate-smart strategies for Chennai’s future.
data.seoMetaDescription: The Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs host a national convening for city leaders from across India.

Bringing together leaders across urban design, policy and implementation, the session explored how cities can use planning as a powerful lever to deliver nature-positive and socially inclusive outcomes.

events.title: Jameel House in Cairo workshops at the 2025 Bayt Yakan summer school

collectionItem.title: Jameel House in Cairo workshops at the 2025 Bayt Yakan summer school

data.title: Jameel House in Cairo workshops at the 2025 Bayt Yakan summer school
data.seoTitle: Jameel House in Cairo workshops at Bayt Yakan
data.description:
The 2025 Bayt Yakan summer school features a programme of workshops in traditional crafts for families from Al-Darb Al-Ahmar, delivered by alumni from the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo.

Seven alumni of the Jameel House in Cairo – Reham Wahba, Sara El Sayed, Amal Mostafa, Ibrahim Waheed, Alya Gamal, Areej Niazi and Hoda Haro – lead the programme, which also includes a visit to the National Museum of Egyptian Civilisation.

Participants will explore traditional craftsmanship by producing handmade backgammon sets rooted in Cairo’s design heritage, having developed skills in geometric design, Arabic calligraphy, brass inlay, wood veneer and stencil printing.

The programme aims to engage children and their families in creative activity and raise awareness of the area's local architectural and craft heritage.

An exhibition and closing ceremony will be held on the 7 September 2025 following the end of the programme.
data.seoMetaDescription: Summer workshops teach families from Al-Darb Al-Ahmar to use traditional crafts to make backgammon sets.

events.title: Jameel Index Forum: Food trade in the current age of uncertainty

collectionItem.title: Jameel Index Forum: Food trade in the current age of uncertainty

data.title: Jameel Index Forum: Food trade in the current age of uncertainty
data.address: Oxford Martin School, University of Oxford
data.seoTitle: Jameel Index Forum at Oxford Martin School
data.description:
The official launch of the Jameel Index for Food Trade and Vulnerability, a new online platform designed to assess countries' exposure to shocks in the global food trade, takes place in the Oxford Martin School at the University of Oxford.

The launch event – the Jameel Index Forum: Food trade in the current age of uncertainty – features two presentations and an expert panel will offer historical perspectives and future projections on food trade, drawing from the Jameel Index and global expertise.

The Jameel Index was developed by the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in collaboration with the University of Oxford and the International Food Policy Research Institute and supported by Community Jameel.

As global food trade increasingly impacts food security, the Jameel Index helps stakeholders assess historical, near-term and future vulnerabilities to trade shocks.

The official launch event introduces the Jameel Index, highlighting its application in analysing the BRICS trade group.

Amidst global challenges to food trade, the expanding BRICS group – comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa, Egypt, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Iran and the United Arab Emirates – holds significant influence as agricultural trade heavyweights.

Brazil hosts COP30 in 2025 and is prioritising sustainable food systems in the agenda.

While the BRICS group accounts for significant global grain production, consumption and exports, its collective role in shaping agricultural trade policies and ensuring food security remains underexplored.

metadata.title: Jameel Index | Measuring food trade and vulnerability
metadata.description: The Jameel Index measures over 160 countries' exposure to global food security vulnerability, dependence on global trade and regional threats impacting the trade of food goods. Major food importing countries, like Algeria and Botswana, and small island states, like Cabo Verde, are highly vulnerable, according to the index.

events.title: 2025 MSF Scientific Day: Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner beta launch

collectionItem.title: 2025 MSF Scientific Day: Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner beta launch

data.title: 2025 MSF Scientific Day: Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner beta launch
data.seoTitle: Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner beta launch
data.description:
The beta version of the Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner, a new data modelling platform developed by the Jameel Institute–Realtime Intelligent Support for Emergencies (Jameel Institute–RISE), is being showcased at the 2025 Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Scientific Day conference on 22 May 2025 at the Royal Society of Medicine in London.

The platform will enable humanitarian practitioners to model the impacts of vaccination discontinuation in crises.

The MSF annual Scientific Day aims to highlight medical research from fragile and conflict-affected settings, bringing together researchers, innovators, and advocates in humanitarian global health.

As part of the event, Jameel Institute co-principal investigators Dr Bhargavi Rao and Dr OJ Watson are hosting a live demo of the Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner aimed at humanitarian actors and data scientists.

The Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner is built and developed by the Jameel Institute at Imperial College and the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, with support from Community Jameel.

The platform aims to offer crucial data-driven insights to international agencies and transform humanitarian response in conflict zones.

This year’s MSF Scientific Day will also include a panel discussion on how to tackle malnutrition in an era of shrinking budgets, shifting political priorities and escalating needs, as well as sessions on neglected tropical diseases and how research is used to inform frontline programming, to support humanitarian health teams and the communities they assist.
data.seoMetaDescription: Médecins Sans Frontières Scientific Day 2025 showcases a beta version of the Jameel Institute Crisis Vaccination Planner in London.

events.title: Anastasia Koorn appears in Parsifal at Glyndebourne

collectionItem.title: Anastasia Koorn appears in Parsifal at Glyndebourne

data.title: Anastasia Koorn appears in Parsifal at Glyndebourne
data.seoTitle: Anastasia Koorn appears in Glyndebourne’s Parsifal
data.description:
Anastasia Koorn – 2023-2025 Bocelli-Jameel scholar – performs in the chorus of Wagner’s ‘Parsifal’ this summer for her Glyndebourne festival debut, running from 17 May to 24 June.

Wagner’s final opera ties together the philosophies of Schopenhauer and Buddhism with the medieval chivalric poem ‘Parzival’, which follows the eponymous knight on his quest for the holy grail.

Launched in 2019, the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel scholarship supports full-time students at the Royal College of Music (RCM) in London, the world’s top conservatoire for performing arts.

The RCM awards the scholarship to students on the basis of merit, assessed at audition, and on their need for financial support.
data.seoMetaDescription: The 2023-2025 Bocelli-Jameel scholar joins the chorus for Glyndebourne’s production of Wagner’s last work.

events.title: MIT J-WAFS 10th anniversary celebration

collectionItem.title: MIT J-WAFS 10th anniversary celebration

data.title: MIT J-WAFS 10th anniversary celebration
data.seoTitle: MIT J-WAFS 10th anniversary celebration
data.description:
MIT J-WAFS marks its 10th anniversary with a celebration on campus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

Taking place at the MIT Welcome Centre, the event reflects on J-WAFS’s impact over the past decade, including celebrating the 400 researchers – across 40 departments, labs and centres – supported by the lab.

The anniversary also recognises the leadership of founding director Professor John H. Lienhard V and founding executive director Renee J. Robins ahead of their retirements.

Finally, the event features remarks by J-WAFS’ new director, Professor Rohit Karnik, who looks ahead to the lab’s bright future.
data.seoMetaDescription: Celebrating 10 years of innovation to secure safe and plentiful food and water for all.

events.title: Seasonings: Seed activism

collectionItem.title: Seasonings: Seed activism

data.title: Seasonings: Seed activism
data.seoTitle: Seasonings: Seed activism with CLIMAVORE x Jameel
data.description:
CLIMAVORE x Jameel at the Royal College of Art (RCA) hosts a symposium addressing the emerging challenges posed to seed health by digital sequencing technologies and artificial intelligence.

The event will also feature the announcement of the recipients of the 2025 CLIMAVORE x Jameel Food Action Awards.

Following introductory remarks by Cooking Sections, principal investigators of CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA, Karine Peschard, associate research fellow of the Geneva Academy of International Humanitarian Law and Human Rights, will deliver a lecture exploring how seed activists have reshaped our relationship to seeds through open-source models, human rights frameworks and the rights of nature.

The lecture concludes by addressing emerging challenges posed by digital sequencing technologies and the use of AI in plant genetic engineering.

Established in 2023, CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA is a research initiative that reimagines foodways for drylands and wetlands.

A partnership between CLIMAVORE and Community Jameel at the RCA, it advances ecological networks to produce new knowledge and action towards spatial justice.
data.seoMetaDescription: CLIMAVORE x Jameel announces the recipients of the 2025 Food Action Awards.

data.seoTitle: Clara Barbier Serrano performs at West Wicklow festival
data.description:
The soprano Clara Barbier Serrano – 2020-2022 Bocelli-Jameel scholar – performs in a trio with saxophonist Robert Finegan and pianist Joanna Kacperek at the ‘Rising stars’ concert of the West Wicklow Chamber Festival in Ireland on 10 May 2025.

The trio will perform a recital, entitled ‘Paris chapters’, inspired by Irish writers in Paris, weaving together the poetry of Yeats, Joyce and Wilde with music by Parisian icons Francis Poulenc and Josephine Baker.

About the Bocelli-Jameel scholarship

Launched in 2019, the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel scholarship supports full-time students at the Royal College of Music (RCM) in London, the world’s top conservatoire for performing arts.

The RCM awards the scholarship to students on the basis of merit, assessed at audition, and on their need for financial support.
data.seoMetaDescription: The 2020-2022 Bocelli-Jameel scholar performs alongside Robert Finegan and Joanna Kacperek in a recital on 10 May 2025 in Ireland.

events.title: Healing Arts Singapore at the 2025 Philanthropy Asia Summit

collectionItem.title: Healing Arts Singapore at the 2025 Philanthropy Asia Summit

data.title: Healing Arts Singapore at the 2025 Philanthropy Asia Summit
data.seoTitle: Healing Arts Singapore at 2025 Philanthropy Asia Summit
data.description:
Community Jameel, the Jameel Arts & Health Lab and Goals House, in association with the Philanthropy Asia Summit, co-host a private reception for partners to come together to develop new ways for the arts to measurably improve health and wellbeing in Singapore.

The evening looks ahead to establishing a Jameel Arts & Health Lab centre of excellence in the country and convening a nationwide arts and health initiative: Healing Arts Singapore.

The evening features remarks by:

  • Fady Jameel, vice chairman, Community Jameel
  • Shaun Seow, chief executive officer, Philanthropy Asia Alliance
  • Ong Zhen Min, director of learning & public engagement and content publishing, National Gallery Singapore
  • Kat Agres, director, Centre for Music and Health, Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music, National University of Singapore
  • Michael Tan, dean of research and knowledge exchange, University of the Arts Singapore
  • Uzma Sulaiman, associate director, Community Jameel
  • Cléa Daridan, head of arts and culture, Community Jameel

The evening concludes with a performance by students from the Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music, followed by an open discussion and networking dinner, curated by chef Yoshihiro Narisaw.

The event follows the success of Healing Arts Scotland, which directly led to the Scottish government integrating arts-in-health approaches into efforts to reduce health inequality affecting over 5 million people in Scotland.
data.seoMetaDescription: Community Jameel and the Jameel Arts & Health Lab co-host a private reception introducing Healing Arts Singapore.

events.title: CGIAR Science Week: Testing and scaling innovations for a climate-secure future

collectionItem.title: CGIAR Science Week: Testing and scaling innovations for a climate-secure future

data.title: CGIAR Science Week: Testing and scaling innovations for a climate-secure future
data.seoTitle: CGIAR Science Week: Testing and scaling innovations
data.description:
Community Jameel and CGIAR co-host a reception at the inaugural CGIAR Science Week to highlight the importance of testing and scaling innovations, including agricultural technologies, to tackle food insecurity.

With remarks by George Richards, director of Community Jameel, Ismahane Elouafi, executive managing director of CGIAR, and Appolinaire Djikeng, director general of the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI), the reception also showcases key support for food systems innovation.

For Community Jameel, this includes:

  • the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action, a partnership between Community Jameel, ILRI, the University of Edinburgh, Save the Children and J-PAL, and
  • the 2025 MIT J-WAFS Grand Challenges grant, supporting a team of researchers from MIT (including from J-PAL) and Kenyatta University, led by Professor Christopher Voigt, to replace harmful agrochemicals with microbes for sustainable agriculture.

The reception is also in association with the COP30 Food Systems Transformation Science and Philanthropy Advisory Group, which brings together researchers and philanthropies to unlock private capital and advance rigorous scientific evidence in support of key COP30 food systems goals.
data.seoMetaDescription: Community Jameel and CGIAR co-host a private reception showcasing J-WAFS Grand Challenges and the Point of Cow device.

events.title: Jameel House in Jeddah 10th anniversary celebration

collectionItem.title: Jameel House in Jeddah 10th anniversary celebration

data.title: Jameel House in Jeddah 10th anniversary celebration
data.seoTitle: Event: Jameel House in Jeddah anniversary
data.description:
Community Jameel, The King's Foundation School of Traditional Arts, Art Jameel and the Nafisa Shams Academy co-host a reception at Hayy Jameel to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Jeddah.

With an exhibition of works and products by alumni of the Jameel House in Jeddah and the Nafisa Shams Academy, the reception features: 

Welcoming remarks

  • George Richards, director, Community Jameel
  • Maria Alem, head of learning, Hayy Jameel
  • Dr May Taibah, director, Nafisa Shams

Panel discussion with Jameel House in Jeddah alumni

  • Rana Alamoudi
  • Rana Tashkandi
  • Manar Kunid
  • Marwa Turkestani
  • Cléa Daridan, head of arts and learning, Community Jameel (moderator)
  • Suzy Wadin, arts and culture programmes officer, Community Jameel (facilitator)

About the Jameel House in Jeddah

Located in Al-Balad in historic Jeddah, the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Jeddah was a centre for traditional crafts education that operated from 2015 to 2021.

With a mission to preserve and champion traditional arts in Saudi Arabia, around 90 students graduated from the Jameel House in Jeddah’s one-year training programme, which was developed and delivered by The King’s Foundation School of Traditional Art, according to the same principles and standards as the courses at its London campus.

The Jameel House in Jeddah is part of a network of Jameel Houses worldwide developed as a partnership between Community Jameel and The King’s Foundation.

The network also includes the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo and the Jameel House of World Traditional Arts in Scotland.
data.seoMetaDescription: Community Jameel, Art Jameel and Nafisa Shams co-host a private exhibition, panel and dinner celebrating 10 years of the Jameel House in Jeddah.

events.title: Alliance for Data, Evaluation, and Policy Training (ADEPT) launch in São Paulo

collectionItem.title: Alliance for Data, Evaluation, and Policy Training (ADEPT) launch in São Paulo

data.title: Alliance for Data, Evaluation, and Policy Training (ADEPT) launch in São Paulo
data.seoTitle: Event: ADEPT launch in São Paulo, Brazil
data.description:
The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Community Jameel launch the Alliance for Data, Evaluation, and Policy Training (ADEPT) at Insper in São Paulo, Brazil.

ADEPT is a global network of campuses and partners committed to training the next generation of researchers and decision-makers in policy evaluation and data analysis.

Bringing together researchers, policymakers and institutional partners, the launch event highlights ADEPT’s mission, objectives and the importance of building local capacity for evidence-based decision-making.

With remarks by Professor Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of J-PAL and 2019 Nobel laureate in economics, and other speakers, a panel discusses ADEPT’s approach to training, partnerships with academic and policy institutions and its role in strengthening the use of rigorous evidence to inform policy worldwide.

This event also marks Insper’s membership of ADEPT and features a second panel discussing ADEPT’s relevance in the region and the diversity of alliance partners.

Panel 1: Introducing ADEPT

  • Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of J-PAL and Abdul Latif Jameel professor of poverty alleviation and development economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)
  • Sara Fisher Ellison, professor and senior lecturer in economics, MIT
  • George Richards, director, Community Jameel
  • Sarah Kopper, director of ADEPT, J-PAL (moderator)

Panel 2: Building an evidence-to-policy ecosystem in Latin America and the Caribbean​ (LAC)

  • Alessandra Benedito, diversity coordinator, FGV Direito
  • Sergio Firpo, Instituto Unibanco chair professor, Insper
  • Maria José da Silva, secretary of state for women and human rights, Alagoas
  • Sergio Lazzarini, Chafi Haddad professor of management, Insper
  • Ariana Britto, policy manager, J-PAL (moderator)

Speeches:

  • Claudia Macías, deputy executive director, J-PAL LAC
  • Guilherme Martins, president, Insper
  • Hugues Kouadio, director, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Statistique et d’Economie Appliquée d’Abidjan
  • Steven Petric, dean of graduate admissions, Princeton University
  • Ivan Brant, senior policy associate, J-PAL LAC

‍

data.title: Anastasia Koorn and Henna Mun lead in ‘Le nozze di Figaro’
data.seoTitle: Event: Bocelli-Jameel Scholars in ‘Le nozze di Figaro’
data.description:
Bocelli-Jameel Scholars Anastasia Koorn and Henna Mun star as Cherubino and Susanna in a Royal College of Music production of Mozart’s ‘Le nozze di Figaro’ held at the Britten Theatre at the RCM from 17-22 March 2025.

The production is directed by acclaimed director, composer and lyricist Jeremy Sams and conducted by the RCM’s director of opera, Michael Rosewell.

Launched in 2019, the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship supports full-time vocal studies students at the RCM.

The RCM awards the scholarship to talented musicians based on merit at audition and their need for support to overcome barriers and access world-class training. Since 2019, the Bocelli-Jameel Scholarship has been awarded to five individuals from four countries.

events.title: The role of evidence and data in driving impact for humanitarian action

collectionItem.title: The role of evidence and data in driving impact for humanitarian action

data.title: The role of evidence and data in driving impact for humanitarian action
data.seoTitle: Event: Evidence and data for humanitarian action
data.description:
Community Jameel and J-PAL MENA co-host a panel discussion at the Riyadh International Humanitarian Forum highlighting how targeted data and evidence-based approaches can inform and enhance humanitarian action.

Using real-world examples, the panel will showcase the Jameel Institute–Realtime Intelligent Support for Emergencies (RISE), which provides data analysis and modelling tools to enhance public health responses in conflict zones, as well as practical guidance for both governments and humanitarian agencies to measure and prioritise effective aid responses during crises.

Launched in 2024, the Jameel Institute-RISE is led by the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London and the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, with a consortium of partners including the World Health Organisation, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, Médecins sans Frontières and the Geneva Water Hub.
data.seoMetaDescription: This Riyadh International Humanitarian Forum event will showcase the Jameel Institute–RISE.

data.seoTitle: 2025 Drylands Summer School
data.description:
With the theme 'Building resilience from below in the face of chronic uncertainty in the drylands', the 2025 Drylands Summer School will be held at Camp Simpirre in Isiolo, Kenya, for around 30 practitioners.

Exploring technical and policy challenges with leading experts in the field, the Drylands Summer School is organised and supported by:

  • the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action‍
  • the Centre for Research and Development in Drylands
  • the Feinstein International Centre at Tufts University
  • the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research
  • the International Livestock Research Institute.

Keynote presentations will be delivered by:

  • Gufu Oba, professor emeritus of the Norwegian University of Life Sciences and director of the Gaadisa Gummi Foundation
  • Ian Scoones, professorial fellow at the Institute of Development Studies and leader of the PASTRES project

metadata.title: Jameel Observatory | Jameel Observatory
metadata.description: We use data and evidence to help governments and communities prepare for and act on environmental shocks as well as those impacts of climate change and variability that threaten human and environmental well-being. With a special focus on low and middle-income countries, we work at the interface of climate, natural disasters, agricultural and food systems, and health.

events.title: Africa launch of the Jameel C40 Climate Action Guide

collectionItem.title: Africa launch of the Jameel C40 Climate Action Guide

data.title: Africa launch of the Jameel C40 Climate Action Guide
data.seoTitle: Africa launch of Jameel C40 Climate Action Guide
data.description:
On 19-21 February 2025, the Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Action Labs and UrbanShift come together for the Africa launch of the Climate Action Guide for Urban Planners at the UrbanShift Africa Forum 2025.

The guide will be featured at two sessions:

  • 19 February: An open session, entitled ‘Climate resilient urban planning’, on the third day of the UrbanShift Africa Forum 2025.
  • 20-21 February: A closed-door session for technical officials entitled ‘City Academy: Accommodating urban growth’.

During the two-day closed-door session, participants engage in interactive discussions and exercises led by C40 Cities, examining real-world urban planning policies and regulations, bringing together urban planners, policymakers and city officials from across Africa and beyond. These practical activities reinforce key concepts, helping attendees gain not only theoretical knowledge but also the skills to integrate climate change considerations into urban planning in their own cities.

events.title: Launch: Hub of Advanced Policy Innovation for the Environment

collectionItem.title: Launch: Hub of Advanced Policy Innovation for the Environment

data.title: Launch: Hub of Advanced Policy Innovation for the Environment
data.seoTitle: Launch of the HAPIE policy lab in Egypt
data.description:
On Tuesday, 18 February 2025, HE Dr Rania Al-Mashat, minister of planning, economic development and international cooperation, the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) MENA regional office, based at the American University in Cairo (AUC), and Community Jameel launch the Hub for Advanced Policy Innovation for the Environment (HAPIE).

The event includes keynote remarks and a panel discussion from distinguished experts and stakeholders addressing Egypt's climate challenges.

HAPIE joins a network of Air and Water Labs, a global initiative founded by J-PAL and Community Jameel. The new lab extends the work of the Egypt Impact Lab, housed at the National Institute for Governance and Sustainable Development (NIGSD).

J-PAL Air and Water Labs partner with government agencies to increase access to evidence and spark collaboration with researchers to innovate, test and scale evidence-informed air and water policies. Based in South Asia, Africa and MENA, the labs collectively aim to reach 260 million people.
data.seoMetaDescription: This new policy lab aims to improve Egyptians’ access to clean air and water.

events.title: Premiere of Ankur at COP16 in Riyadh

collectionItem.title: Premiere of Ankur at COP16 in Riyadh

data.title: Premiere of Ankur at COP16 in Riyadh
data.address: Restoration Pavilion, Blue Zone, UNCCD COP16, Riyadh
data.description:
Watch Ankur, an award-winning short documentary film about women in West Bengal banding together to rebuild their lives after devastating tropical cyclones, at the Restoration Pavilion in the Blue Zone at the sixteenth session of the conference of the parties (COP16) of the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) in Riyadh.

‍The screening – which is the film's premiere – follows its official selection by the G20 Global Land Initiative and will feature a short introduction by George Richards, director of Community Jameel and one of the film's producers.‍

Ankur – which means “seedling” in Bengali – tells the story of an eponymous project to empower women-led collectives in the Sundarbans to restore their homes, build new shelters, and revive their farmland and livelihoods using a combination of traditional farming practices and novel techniques.

events.title: Leveraging philanthropic and private sector resources for food systems transformation

collectionItem.title: Leveraging philanthropic and private sector resources for food systems transformation

data.title: Leveraging philanthropic and private sector resources for food systems transformation
data.address: Arab Coordination Group Pavilion, Blue Zone, UNCCD COP16, Riyadh
data.seoTitle: COP16: Philanthropy as a resource for food systems
data.description:
Community Jameel, the United Nations Global Compact, the Islamic Development Bank, Ambition Loop, Goumbook and the World Business Council for Sustainable Development host a roundtable discussion at on how agricultural, climate and emissions roadmaps at the national level can leverage philanthropic and private sector resources to identify and build more resilient food system models.

The meeting will take place at the Arab Coordination Group Pavilion at the sixteenth session of the conference of the parties (COP16) of the UN Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD).

Supporting the Riyadh Action Agenda, this roundtable will bring together key actors from business and philanthropy to address the lack of knowledge, resources, and partnerships needed to define the needs of each country and identify the enablers the private sector can focus on.

The roundtable will be the first in a series of events uniting food systems stakeholders to deliver impacts in key countries in 2025 and identify successful models for replication in the lead-up to the UN Food Systems Summit +4 and UN Climate Change COP30 meeting.
data.seoMetaDescription: How can agricultural, climate and emissions roadmaps leverage philanthropy and private sector resources to build more resilient food system models?

events.title: Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action x UNCCD COP16

collectionItem.title: Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action x UNCCD COP16

data.title: Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action x UNCCD COP16
data.seoTitle: Jameel Observatory at UNCCD COP16 2024
data.description:
The Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action participates in the sixteenth session of the Conference of the Parties (COP16) of the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, where leaders meet to accelerate investment and action to restore land and boost drought resilience.

The Jameel Observatory host a session entitled ‘Accelerating actions for healthy land in East Africa’ to discuss strategies for healthy land management and governance in drylands in the face of droughts and other shocks.

The Jameel Observatory and CGIAR co-organise a second session, entitled 'Scaling innovations for healthier land, livelihoods and livestock in East Africa', in which speakers focus on agri-food system innovations that boost the health of drylands and their reliance against droughts and other shocks. Guyo Roba, director of the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action, is joined by Tahira Mohamed, fellow at the Jameel Observatory and post-doctoral fellow at the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI), and Dereje Wakjida, director of the IGAD centre for pastoral areas and livestock development.
data.seoMetaDescription: Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action hosts side events at UNCCD COP16 in Riyadh

data.title: 2024 Atelier Jameel winter exhibition and sale
data.seoTitle: Atelier Jameel 2024 winter exhibition and sale
data.description:
Atelier Jameel, a collective of traditional craft designers and artisans dedicated to providing artistic and technical opportunities to graduates of the Jameel Houses of Traditional Arts in Cairo, Jeddah and Scotland, opens its 2024 winter exhibition and sale on 5 December at 6pm at the Institut français d'archéologie orientale in Mounira, Cairo.  

Running until 8 December, the exhibition features more than 200 works of jewellery, furnishings, interior decoration and winter seasonal gifts by participating artists, designers and craftspeople, including more than 30 alumni of the Jameel House in Cairo.  

Contemporary works of art and design will be available to buy, with each piece offering a glimpse into the history and heritage of Islamic arts. The exhibition, entitled ‘Reviving traditional craftsmanship and celebrating innovating’, is free and open to all.

About Atelier Jameel

Atelier Jameel is a collective of traditional craft designers and artisans providing economic, artistic and technical opportunities to graduates of the Jameel Houses of Traditional Arts in Cairo, Jeddah and Scotland.
data.seoMetaDescription: Atelier Jameel opens its 2024 winter exhibition and sale with over 200 works by more than 30 alumni of the Jameel House in Cairo.

events.title: Transnational foodways and food citizenship across Türkiye and the Levant

collectionItem.title: Transnational foodways and food citizenship across Türkiye and the Levant

data.title: Transnational foodways and food citizenship across Türkiye and the Levant
data.seoTitle: Symposium: Transnational foodways and food citizenship

heroImage.caption: Image from Salt Research: 'Harvesting in sugar beet field'

data.description:
Salt, in collaboration with CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA, Birkbeck, University of London and Özyeğin University, host a symposium to examine the socio-political implications of of new foodways in Türkiye and the Levant through the lens of transnational food citizenship.

Inspired by CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA’s ‘Water buffalo commons’ project, the symposium focuses on ecologies, terroirs and landscapes over state, nationality and ethnicity as routes into understanding the transfer, adaptation and appropriation of transnational foodways.

It aims to underline the place of distinctive social metabolisms between people and the more-than-human in shaping conceptions of citizenship, belonging and power about food and drink.

The programme will also address particular challenges to food citizenship arising from historical changes linked to human migrations and their associated habitats.

The three-day symposium is free-admission, open to the public and held in English.

metadata.description: Wetlands, mangroves, swamps, bogs, marshes and mudflats have been drained to 'improve' land for centuries. These liminal landscapes are nonetheless important biodiverse habitats, crucial migratory bird stopovers, water-filtering zones, and invaluable buffers against sea flooding and storms, contributing to overall climate resilience.

data.seoTitle: Disruptive | Goals House | Baku at COP29

heroImage.caption: Event artwork containing text: "Disruptive technologies for water and food security | COP29 | 12 November 2024 • 21h00-22h30 • Baku".

data.description:
Community Jameel, CGIAR, the Munich Security Conference Foundation and the COP29 UN Climate Change High-Level Champions host a reception on 12 November 2024 at Goals House in Baku to mark the launch of the COP29 Presidency's Baku Harmoniya Climate Initiative for Farmers. The event will explore the potential of innovation – from traditional agricultural methods to technological breakthroughs – focused on securing sustainable agriculture, food and water for the future.

Attendees will experience how the synergy of traditional wisdom and modern technology can be harnessed to create scalable, effective solutions, as well as advocate for development financiers to continue to invest in research and development and enable local environment and technological solutions. The reception includes live demonstrations by crafts people showcasing traditional practices contributing to sustainable food and water systems, as well as remarks from:

  • George Richards, director of Community Jameel
  • Ismahane Elouafi, executive managing director of CGIAR

data.title: Food trade and global change: Implications for food security in an increasingly uncertain world
data.seoTitle: Jameel Index launched at the 2024 Borlaug Dialogue
data.description:
At the 2024 edition of the prestigious Norman E. Borlaug Dialogue, convened alongside the World Food Prize presentation in Des Moines, Iowa, the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) convenes a breakout session with representatives from the private sector and multilateral institutions.

Exploring multidisciplinary research and cross-sector collaborations towards addressing challenges to global food security, the session includes the launch of the Jameel Index for Food Trade and Vulnerability, hosted by MIT J-WAFS for the Food and Climate Systems Transformation (FACT) Alliance.

Agenda

Opening remarks: Greg Sixt, director of the FACT Alliance, project lead for the Jameel Index and research manager for J-WAFS

Keynote speech and introduction to the Jameel Index: Kenneth Strzepek, project lead for the Jameel Index; senior research fellow for the International Food Policy Research Institute

Panel discussion:

  • Greg Sixt
  • Kenneth Strzepek
  • Paola de Almeida, food and agriculture portfolio head, Pegasus Capital Advisors
  • Linus Mofor, senior environmental affairs officer, African Climate Policy Centre for the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa
  • Shijie Yang, agricultural economist, global agriculture and food security programme, World Bank

metadata.description: The Jameel Index measures over 160 countries' exposure to global food security vulnerability, dependence on global trade and regional threats impacting the trade of food goods. Major food importing countries, like Algeria and Botswana, and small island states, like Cabo Verde, are highly vulnerable, according to the index.

events.title: Harnessing the power of science and technology for global emergencies | Future Resilience Forum 2024

collectionItem.title: Harnessing the power of science and technology for global emergencies | Future Resilience Forum 2024

data.title: Harnessing the power of science and technology for global emergencies | Future Resilience Forum 2024
data.seoTitle: Community Jameel at the Future Resilience Forum 2024
data.description:
As global emergencies - from pandemics and natural disasters to armed conflicts and climate crises - become increasingly complex an interlinked, new technologies and innovative strategies are critical tools in helping to predict, pre-empt and stabilise crises before they escalate.

Despite advancements in fields such as AI, quantum computing, epidemiology, data analytics and climate science, a significant gap exists between cutting-edge innovations and the rapid deployment of solutions in crisis environments.

On 14 October 2024, Community Jameel convenes a panel at the Future Resilience Forum to explore how emerging technologies and scientific advances can mitigate the threats posed by humanitarian emergencies - in terms of both human life and broader insecurity - and the challenges faced in bridging the gap between technological innovation and humanitarian responses, including financing, ethics and the need for better coordination.

The panel is facilitated by George Richards, director, Community Jameel, and includes:

  • Neil Ferguson, director, Jameel Institute, Imperial College London
  • Lieutenant General (retd) Richard Nugee, chair of the secretariat advisory board, All-Party Parliamentary Group for Climate Change and Security
  • Mark Bryson-Richardson, Foreign Secretary's representative for humanitarian affairs in the occupied Palestinian territories, Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office
  • Dana Al Salem, CEO and founder, Merit Capital
data.seoMetaDescription: Community Jameel convenes a panel on the power of science and technology for global emergencies at the Future Resilience Forum 2024

events.title: Culture's healing power: Time to scale up | World Cities Culture Summit 2024

collectionItem.title: Culture's healing power: Time to scale up | World Cities Culture Summit 2024

data.title: Culture's healing power: Time to scale up | World Cities Culture Summit 2024
data.seoTitle: Jameel Arts & Health Lab at WCCS 2024
data.description:
The Jameel Arts & Health Lab participates in the 2024 World Cities Culture Summit in Dubai, where city leaders explore the challenges that global cities face and share opportunities for culture to play a leading role in their response.

In Culture's healing power: Time to scale up, Cléa Daridan, head of arts and culture at Community Jameel, represents the Jameel Arts & Health Lab in a challenge session alongside Jacqueline Rose, senior manager of culture, Creative Industries and 24 Hour London, and Viktoriia Mukha, chairman of the committee on culture, Kyiv City Council, to tackle the question of how to scale up successful projects at the intersection of culture and health.

This session features the announcement of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab's forthcoming evaluation of Healing Arts Scotland, the world's first nationwide festival celebrating and advocating for improved physical, mental and social health through the arts, and the release of a preliminary report highlighting the policy impact of the festival, which was produced in collaboration with Scottish Ballet and took place as part of the Edinburgh International Festival in August 2024.

Read the preliminary Healing Arts Scotland report here. A full evaluation of the event is to be released in December 2024.

In a second session, entitled The future of… data: Proving culture’s value through evidence, speakers explore the use of data and evaluation to make the case for sustained support on culture. Cléa Daridan is joined by Bruno Truzzi, senior data analyst, Itaú Foudation, and Ekatarina Travkina, co-ordinator of culture, creative industries and global events, Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.
data.seoMetaDescription: Cléa Daridan shares preliminary findings from the Jameel Arts & Health Lab of the impact of Healing Arts Scotland.

data.title: Mawheba | Emerging musical talent in Egypt
data.seoTitle: Supporting emerging musical talent in Egypt.
data.description:
The Royal College of Music (RCM) in London, the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development and Community Jameel, in partnership with the Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM), invite young string and vocal talents, from age 14 and 16 respectively, to participate in Mawheba, a programme supporting emerging classical / opera singers and string musicians in Egypt.

Taking place in Cairo from 4-6 November 2024, Mawheba comprises a series of masterclasses, workshops and Q&As and is an unmissable opportunity to perform to RCM professors and receive immediate feedback within a friendly and supportive environment. The programme culminates in a performance at the GEM.

The RCM is the global number-one institution for the performing arts according to the QS World University Rankings for 2022, 2023 and 2024.

For more details on how to apply, please see here.

Applications close on 14 October 2024.

events.title: Navigating the polycrisis: Evidence-based policy for resilient cities | WUF12

collectionItem.title: Navigating the polycrisis: Evidence-based policy for resilient cities | WUF12

data.title: Navigating the polycrisis: Evidence-based policy for resilient cities | WUF12
data.seoTitle: Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs at WUF12
data.description:
Cities are both highly vulnerable and significant contributors to climate change. Rising inequality, conflicts and political division add layers to the current polycrisis. These challenges demand urgent and decisive action.

Community Jameel and C40 Cities – co-founders of the Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs – co-convene a panel discussion at the World Urban Forum in Cairo, Egypt, on 5 November 2024 from 11h00-12h30.

Showcasing work supported by the Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Lab in Amman, Jordan, and innovative models to support cities' integration of climate action into their strategic planning at both the local and national levels, the event will see the unveiling of the Climate Action Guide for Urban Planners, a resource of practical tips and case studies developed by UrbanShift and the Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs. With perspectives from the UN, government and research, this session analyses successes, openings and new pathways for collaboration to accelerate climate resilience action.

The panel is facilitated by Hélène Chartier, director of urban planning and design at C40, and includes:

  • Yousef Shawarbeh, mayor of Amman
  • Laia Bonet, deputy mayor for urbanism, ecological transition, mobility and housing for UN-Habitat
  • Ahmed Elsayed, executive director of J-PAL MENA
  • Ahmed K. AbuLaban, chief resilience officer and city director of Ramallah

events.title: Jameel-Toyota Scholarship 30th anniversary

collectionItem.title: Jameel-Toyota Scholarship 30th anniversary

data.title: Jameel-Toyota Scholarship 30th anniversary
data.seoTitle: Jameel-Toyota Scholarship 30th anniversary at MIT
data.description:
Community Jameel and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Jameel-Toyota Scholarship with a luncheon honouring current and past scholars at MIT's Samberg Conference Centre on 25 September 2024.

The event includes remarks from Fady Jameel, vice chairman of Community Jameel, Melissa Nobles, chancellor of MIT and Sally Kornbluth, president of MIT. A networking dessert provides the opportunity for current and past scholars to network with MIT senior leadership as well as leadership and researchers of J-PAL, J-WAFS, J-WEL and the MIT Jameel Clinic and Community Jameel.

The Jameel-Toyota Scholarship was founded in 1994 to ease financial barriers for first-year MIT undergraduate students from around the world. The scholarship is named in recognition of the long-standing and close relationship between the Jameel family and the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan. To date, the scholarship has supported more than 215 students from 27 countries, and has enabled opportunities for students who are refugees, asylum-seekers and internally-displaced persons.

events.title: UNFAO | Second drylands summer school

collectionItem.title: UNFAO | Second drylands summer school

data.title: UNFAO | Second drylands summer school
data.seoTitle: UNFAO hosts second 'Drylands summer school' in Kenya
data.description:
FAO hosts second ‘Drylands summer school' in Kenya.

Supported by the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) G20 Global Land Initiative and Community Jameel, the second 'Drylands summer school' aims to train a community of experts on building and managing more resilient drylands.

The agenda includes a session on monitoring drylands facilitated by Guyo Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action, based at the International Institute for Livestock Research (ILRI) in Kenya.

Convened by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation's (FAO) Working Group on Dryland Forests and Agrosilvopastoral Systems, dryland foresters and silvopastoral practitioners, as well as planners and policymakers, come together to improve their current and planned actions in drylands and rangelands, and deepen their knowledge on how to create contextual solutions to address the key issues facing agrosilvopastoral systems.

Over the course of four days, representatives from research institutes and universities facilitate group work sessions, case study presentations and a field trip to Tiva Woodland, a sub-centre of the Kitui Dryland Eco-Regional Research Programme.
data.seoMetaDescription: FAO holds second ‘Drylands summer school' in Kenya, in partnership with Jameel Observatory and supported by Community Jameel and G20 Global Land Initiative

collectionItem.title: J-WAFS at 10: Celebrating a decade of innovation

data.title: J-WAFS at 10: Celebrating a decade of innovation
data.address: Goals House, Tavern on the Green, New York City
data.description:
Community Jameel and the MIT Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) co-host a reception to celebrate J-WAFS' 10-year anniversary and showcase J-WAFS flagship online platform, the Jameel Index for Food Trade and Vulnerability.

The Jameel Index measures and assesses countries' dependence on global food trade and imports, and how regional-scale threats might affect the ability to trade food goods across diverse geographic regions.

The event hosts a discussion with members of the Jameel Index advisory committee Joel Bourne and Tracy McVeigh and a preview of George Steinmetz's upcoming book, 'Feed the planet', a photographic journey of how global food systems are changing our planet.

events.title: Food and water: Securing vital resources

collectionItem.title: Food and water: Securing vital resources

data.title: Food and water: Securing vital resources
data.seoTitle: Food and water: Securing vital resources
data.description:
Access to water and food is critical to societal stability and is a key national and global security issue. The impact of water and food insecurity, compounded by climate change, migration and conflict, can have a destabilising affect, triggering wider crises and transcending national boundaries.  

At UNGA 79, the Spanish government, Community Jameel, Chatham House, Almar Water Solutions and the MIT Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) are bringing together policy makers, academics and the defence sector on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly 79 to discuss the levers that link water stress and food insecurity to global instability, with a specific focus on international trade and security.

The discussion will showcase the work that the Spanish government is undertaking to preserve its own water resources and its strategy internationally. The event will also remarks from feature remarks from the CEO of Almar Water Solutions - a division of Abdul Latif Jameel Energy, insights from Chatham House's research as part of the UK-funded Fair Water Footprints Partnership on tackling global trade-related water risks, as well as a preview of the soon-to-be released data from the Jameel Index for Food trade and Vulnerability - an MIT platform on the implications of climate change on the trade of food.
data.seoMetaDescription: Community Jameel and partners host food and water security event at Instituto Cervantes on the sidelines of UNGA 79 in New York, NY.

events.title: Clara Barbier Serrano | Les Arènes Lyriques

collectionItem.title: Clara Barbier Serrano | Les Arènes Lyriques

data.title: Clara Barbier Serrano | Les Arènes Lyriques
data.seoTitle: Clara Barbier Serrano performs with Les Arènes Lyriques
data.description:
Former Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel scholar Clara Barbier Serrano performs at the 2024 edition of Les Arènes Lyriques, Montmartre's concert.

Held in a little-known arena garden in Montmartre, Paris, each year, Les Arènes Lyriques brings together a unique group of young soloists, including violinists, singers and pianists, to perform an ephemeral musical programme, devised by them and performed just ten times.

This summer, French soprano Clara performs solo pieces as well as part of ensembles with other early-career musicians, all accompanied by musicians from the Ostinato Orchestra. The musical programme, with arrangements by Loan Boulat and David Walter, include Wagner's 'La Mort d’Isolde', Tchaïkovski's 'Souvenir d’un lieu cher : I. Méditation', and Parra's 'Gracias a la vida', among others.

Clara was the first recipient of the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship, which was established in 2019 to support emerging opera talent to study full-time at the Royal College of Music in London.
data.seoMetaDescription: Former Bocelli-Jameel scholar Clara Barbier Serrano performs in the heart of the Monmartre arena gardens in Paris as part of Les Arènes Lyriques.

events.title: Healing Arts Scotland

collectionItem.title: Healing Arts Scotland

data.title: Healing Arts Scotland
data.seoTitle: Healing Arts Scotland launches with countrywide events
data.description:
The Jameel Arts and Health Lab and Scottish Ballet present Healing Arts Scotland, a week-long celebration of the importance of the arts to physical, mental and social health.

Taking place between 19-23 August 2024, key events include an opening celebration performance at the Scottish Parliament, two days of speakers and panel discussions on the healing effects of the arts as part of Edinburgh International Festival, a wellbeing concert in Glasgow and a series of special events in Aberdeen, Orkney, Lewis and at Dumfries House, home of The King's Foundation.

In an aim to highlight how many brilliant events take place across Scotland, encouraging more people to take part, everyone across Scotland is welcome to register an event they would like to be included on the Healing Arts Scotland website.

To find out more, visit: healingartsscotland.org

collectionItem.title: POSTPONED: Launch: Hub of Advanced Policy Innovation for the Environment

data.title: POSTPONED: Launch: Hub of Advanced Policy Innovation for the Environment
data.seoTitle: Launch of J-PAL MENA Air and Water Lab: HAPIE
data.description:
On Tuesday 18 February, 2025, the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) MENA regional office based at the American University in Cairo (AUC) and Community Jameel launch the Hub for Advanced Policy Innovation for the Environment (HAPIE).

The event includes keynote remarks and panel discussions from distinguished experts and stakeholders addressing Egypt's climate challenges.

HAPIE joins a network of Air and Water Labs, a global initiative founded by J-PAL and Community Jameel. The new lab extends the work of the Egypt Impact Lab, housed at the National Institute for Governance and Sustainable Development (NIGSD).

J-PAL Air and Water Labs partner with government agencies to increase access to evidence and spark collaboration with researchers to innovate, test, and scale evidence-informed air and water policies. Based in South Asia, Africa and MENA, the labs collectively aim to reach 260 million people.

events.title: POSTPONED: Launch: Morocco Innovation and Evaluation Lab

collectionItem.title: POSTPONED: Launch: Morocco Innovation and Evaluation Lab

data.title: POSTPONED: Launch: Morocco Innovation and Evaluation Lab
data.seoTitle: Launch of the Morocco Innovation and Evaluation Lab
data.description:
The Morocco Innovation and Evaluation Lab (MEL) launches on 2-5 July 2024 at the University Mohammed VI Polytechnic (UM6P) in Rabat. The lab is a joint initiative with the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) in partnership with the Centre for International Development (CID) at Harvard University and Community Jameel.

The lab, which is hosted at UM6P, will expand on the work of the previous Morocco Employment Lab with a broadened scope beyond employment and labour market to include sectors such as education, firms, social protection, climate change and agriculture.

The four-day launch event convenes participants from diverse backgrounds to learn about past accomplishments and future objectives, discuss Morocco's development challenges and priorities, build capacity amongst decision-makers to conduct rigorous impact evaluations and foster connections between researchers from the MEL network and decision-makers.

On 2 July, a one-day conference includes a keynote speech from co-founder and co-director of J-PAL and Nobel laureate in economics, Esther Duflo, remarks from the lab's director Florencia Devoto, scientific co-directors Rema Hanna and Bruno Crépon and Community Jameel director George Richards, as well as a high-level session and three thematic panels.

On 3-5 July, a three-day comprehensive training course convenes thirty participants from public institutions, academia, private sector and non-profit organisations to explore the fundamental concepts and methods of impact evaluations, followed by a networking session.
data.seoMetaDescription: The Morocco Innovation and Evaluation Lab (MEL) launches in Rabat on 2-5 July 2024

events.title: Workshop on the economics of pandemic preparedness

collectionItem.title: Workshop on the economics of pandemic preparedness

data.title: Workshop on the economics of pandemic preparedness
data.seoTitle: Workshop on the economics of pandemic preparedness
data.description:
The Jameel Institute at Imperial College London and the Umeå School of Business, Economics and Statistics in Stockholm invite researchers, scholars and policymakers to submit papers for the first 'Workshop on the economics of pandemic preparedness.' This two-day event aims to provide a platform for sharing and discussing current research, ideas, projects and agenda concerning the economic impacts of pandemics, health system resilience to pandemics and human behaviour during pandemics, in an informal, friendly and relaxed atmosphere.

The workshop hosts representatives from the Jameel Institute including Katharina Hauck, deputy director of the Jameel Institute, alongside Patrick Doohan, a mathematical modeller at the Jameel Institute, as well as keynote speakers Edith Patouillard, health economist at the World Health Organisation and professor Aditya Goenka, chair in economics at the University of Birmingham.

They are joined by students and researchers from various universities including Imperial College London, Stockholm University, University of Oslo, Brunel University London, Ateneo de Manila University and University of Strasbourg, among others.

The workshop encourages submissions of papers on a wide range of topics related to the economics of pandemic preparedness, such as:

1. Economic modelling and analysis of pandemics and their impact on economies
2. Cost-benefit analyses of public health interventions during pandemics
3. Health system resilience and its economic implications
4. Integrated econ-epi models
5. Behavioural aspects of preparedness
6. Lessons learned from past pandemics
data.seoMetaDescription: The Jameel Institute and Umeå University call host the first 'Workshop on the economics of pandemic preparedness' in Stockholm, 19-20 June 2024.

events.title: POSTPONED: Islamic Development Bank and Community Jameel strategic partnership launch

collectionItem.title: POSTPONED: Islamic Development Bank and Community Jameel strategic partnership launch

data.title: POSTPONED: Islamic Development Bank and Community Jameel strategic partnership launch
data.seoTitle: Islamic Development Bank & Community Jameel partnership
data.description:
Community Jameel and the Islamic Development Bank (IsDB) announce a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to collaborate strategically to tackle poverty, disease, hunger and the effects of climate change, including supporting evidence generation and informing cross-sectional policy development in IsDB member countries.

The MoU is signed by IsDB president HE Dr Muhammad Al Jasser and Community Jameel chairman HE Mr Mohammed Jameel KBE at a virtual signing ceremony on 4 July 2024.

The MoU focuses on critical development issues including food security and sustainable urban design in the face of climate change, informing public health responses to emerging threats and leveraging evidence to enhance policy design. Under the MoU, the IsDB and Community Jameel also partners with the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) to advance evidence-based policymaking in IsDB member countries.

The MoU additionally explores opportunities to address risks to public health resulting from several factors, including climate change and a rise in noncommunicable diseases through the Jameel Institute, expand access to cutting-edge AI tools to mainstream healthcare facilities through the Jameel Clinic AI Hospital Network and explore leveraging climate data, forecasting and technology through the Jameel Observatory.

The MoU serves to reiterate the long-standing relationship between Community Jameel and the IsDB as they work together to achieve their common objectives. In June 2022, the two organisations announced their plans to work together at the IsDB annual meetings in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, with the aim of promoting evidence-based policymaking through the launch of embedded labs.

Mohammed Jameel says: "Science and evidence lie at the heart of our work at Community Jameel to empower communities and offer long-term, sustainable solutions to some of the most pressing challenges faced by our world today. From climate change to enhanced education, to identifying the right policies to create for the most impact, we are proud to be partnering with the IsDB as we work to solve some of the most pressing challenges within its member countries."
data.seoMetaDescription: Islamic Development Bank and Community Jameel launch strategic partnership to enhance policymaking in IsDB member countries

data.title: Atelier Jameel x Bayt Yakan Summer School
data.seoTitle: Atelier Jameel and Bayt Yakan host Cairo Summer School
data.description:
Atelier Jameel and Bayt Yakan host a Summer School of courses in traditional crafts and arts at Bayt Yakan's premises in Cairo's historic Al-Darb Al-Ahmar neighbourhood, led by graduates of the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo.

Eleven Jameel House graduates, under the name Atelier Jameel, will lead a programme offering 15 traditional craft courses and two visits to the Museum of Islamic Art and Muizz Street to residents of Al-Darb Al-Ahmar.

The programme aims to provide a community hub for creative activity and awareness of the area's local architectural and craft heritage, and to create teaching opportunities for Jameel House alumni who can pass on their knowledge and skills to the next generation.

events.title: Jameel Observatory x Save the Children: Early warning systems and anticipatory action for tackling hunger and insecurity

collectionItem.title: Jameel Observatory x Save the Children: Early warning systems and anticipatory action for tackling hunger and insecurity

data.title: Jameel Observatory x Save the Children: Early warning systems and anticipatory action for tackling hunger and insecurity
data.seoTitle: Early action for drought solutions and resilience
data.description:
Six months on from the Global Food Security Summit, hosted at Lancaster House by the UK, UAE and Somali governments, and COP28 in Dubai, this meeting brings together policymakers, development actors, scientists and the private sector to spur investment in new technologies and innovative solutions for enhancing food security and resilience in the Horn of Africa.

Convening at the House of Lords, the meeting features a technical roundtable discussion and pre-publication preview of a new report on anticipatory action for the food and nutrition crisis in the Horn of Africa, by the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action and Save the Children.​

This follows an earlier report published by the Jameel Observatory and Save the Children in April 2024, and the Dangerous Delay 2 report published in 2022 by the Jameel Observatory, Save the Children and Oxfam. ​
data.seoMetaDescription: Policymakers, development actors, scientists and private sector convene to spur investment in solutions for food security and resilience in Africa.

events.title: SEASONINGS: Water buffalo commons & monoculture meltdown

collectionItem.title: SEASONINGS: Water buffalo commons & monoculture meltdown

data.title: SEASONINGS: Water buffalo commons & monoculture meltdown
data.seoTitle: CLIMAVORE x Jameel at the RCA lecture | 21 May 2024
data.description:
CLIMAVORE x Jameel at the RCA presents 'SEASONINGS' on 21 May 2024 at 18h00 at the School of Architecture at the Royal College of Art Kensington campus. The lecture will introduce the research developed at CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA, including 'Water buffalo commons' in Istanbul and 'Monoculture meltdown' in Italy. Aurora Fredriksen will provide a response and the event will culminate in a question and answer session. This event is open to the public.

CLIMAVORE x Jameel at the RCA reimagines foodways for drylands and wetlands in the climate crisis. It advances ecological networks to produce new knowledge and action towards spatial justice. Since 2022 the research has focused on two human-made seasons.

'Water buffalo commons' looks at a season of wetland disappearance in Istanbul, where herders, pastures, buffalos and other companion species are creating new ecologies on the ruins of post-industrial habitats while resisting the encroachment of the city.

'Monoculture meltdown' looks at a season of drought in Sicily and Apulia, Italy, joining farmers in the effort to challenge the leftovers of intensive food production by cultivating the rights of ancient seeds resisting heat and water stress for the future generations.

‍

events.title: Manda Festivali 2024

collectionItem.title: Manda Festivali 2024

data.title: Manda Festivali 2024
data.seoTitle: Join the Manda Festivali 2024 in Istanbul
data.description:
An annual water-buffalo festival celebrating the presence and permanence of pastoralist practices in Istanbul’s wetlands, Manda Festivali is organised by CLIMAVORE x Jameel at the Royal College of Art – a partnership between Cooking Sections, Community Jameel and the RCA – in collaboration with the Istanbul Foundation for Culture and Arts (IKSV).

Bringing together local herders, musicians, environmentalists, artists, biologists, cheese makers and the general public, the festival offers walks, performances, workshops, the first ever herder and buffalo portrait competition, and tasting of buffalo milk products.

In its third year, the festival offers Istanbul’s residents, food producers and ecologists an opportunity to come together and cherish the wetlands and the buffalos and the herders that protect.

data.title: Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action: Community of practice meeting
data.seoTitle: Jameel Observatory Community of Practice - May 2024
data.description:
The third Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action community of practice meeting is an opportunity for the Jameel Observatory's network of practitioners to jointly take stock of different research and evidence efforts within the community and among partners, review results emerging from its impact collaborations, identify promising innovations for rapid testing and dissemination, review capacity development needs and plan collaborative actions to advance dryland policy priorities in the region.

The two-day event takes place at the International Livestock Research Institute campus in Nairobi and consists of workshops and presentations reviewing the community's efforts, research and impact collaborations as well as providing a dedicated space to share early-career and next-generation perspectives on the issues under discussion.

events.title: Addressing climate inequality

collectionItem.title: Addressing climate inequality

data.title: Addressing climate inequality
data.seoTitle: Esther Duflo addresses the London School of Economics
data.description:
A central issue with climate change is that those who contribute least to the problem are being most effected. As part of the LSE Environment Camp happening between 2-3 May, LSE hosts a public event featuring speakers Esther Duflo, the co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), and Shweta Banerjee, head of BRAC International in India to present new thinking on how to design and finance loss and damage funds. The event is chaired by Oriana Bandiera, the Sir Anthony Atkinson Professor of Economics at the London School of Economics, and also examines how these funds might be best spent to protect vulnerable populations against the effects of climate change.

The LSE Environment Camp is a series of events exploring environmental issues and connecting the work to policy change.

events.title: J-WEL Week 2024: AI4Ed

collectionItem.title: J-WEL Week 2024: AI4Ed

data.title: J-WEL Week 2024: AI4Ed
data.address: MIT Campus, Hacker Reactor, 7th Floor, iHQ Building
data.seoTitle: J-WEL Week 2024: AI4Ed | Generative AI in education
data.description:
The Abdul Latif Jameel World Education Lab (J-WEL) hosts J-WEL Week 2024: AI4Ed on 6-9 May 2024 at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) campus in Cambridge, MA, USA. This year's edition of J-WEL Week explores generative AI in education and advances collective conversations about how best to serve all learners through the use of the technology. Members are invited to a series of panels, presentations, co-creation exercises and workshops to promote knowledge share and resource development to benefit campuses, educators and students across the J-WEL network.

On Tuesday, May 7, the event's morning session will be open to the public and live-streamed. The session, 'AI's education revolution: What will it take?', includes remarks from Anjali Sastry, faculty director of J-WEL; Daniel Huttenlocher, dean of the MIT Schwarzman College of Computing and chair of the MIT Jameel Clinic; Andrew Lo, the Charles E. and Susan T. Harris Professor of Finance and director of laboratory and financial engineering at MIT Sloan School of Management; Per Urlaub, director of MIT Global Languages and Eva Dessein, senior lecturer and lead for the French language programme at MIT Global Languages. Register for online attendance to the session here.

data.address: The Royal Society, 6-9 Carlton House Terrace, London SW1Y 5AG
data.seoTitle: Exploring the economics of pandemic preparedness
data.description:
The Jameel Institute at Imperial College London hosts a day of panels and break-out discussions focused on how to navigate the trade-offs in investment between pandemic preparedness and the surveillance, prevention and management of endemic infectious diseases.

Organised in collaboration with Imperial College London's Institute of Infection and Business School, the programme includes talks from a range of organisational, discipline and global perspectives.

George Richards, director of Community Jameel, chairs a panel discussion titled 'Tradeoffs in peacetime and pandemics', exploring how different disciplines can coordinate in an emergency situation and what investments are priority in order to prepare for pandemics and to respond to them.

events.title: MIT-MGB AI Cures conference 2024

collectionItem.title: MIT-MGB AI Cures conference 2024

data.title: MIT-MGB AI Cures conference 2024
data.address:
Markell Conference Center
Mass General Brigham
Somerville, MA
USA
data.seoTitle: Medical and AI experts convene for MIT-MGB AI cures '24
data.description:
AI has transformed many areas of life in the last decade, yet the impact of these technologies on patient care is still limited. Building on the combined expertise of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and Mass General Brigham (MGB) in AI and clinical practice, the MIT-MGB AI Cures conference showcases ongoing collaborative projects in clinical AI, highlighting cutting-edge research and their impact on patient care. The event is co-organised by the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and healthcare at MIT, and will feature keynote speeches and panel discussions with several MIT Jameel Clinic researchers including AI faculty lead Regina Barzilay as well as principal investigators Dina Katabi, Marzyeh Ghassemi and Collin Stultz, among others.

Topics covered during the conference include clinical translation of AI tools, regulatory issues in clinical AI, fairness and equity, secure patient data, among others. The day's proceedings will also include a poster competition and session for presenting abstracts on clinical AI, AI biology, AI systems, AI safety and fairness and AI in drug discovery.
data.seoMetaDescription: MIT Jameel Clinic and Mass General Brigham co-host the AI Cures conference on 1 April 2024 showcasing collaborative projects in clinical AI.

data.description:
Academia-industry collaboration could bridge the gap between theory and practice, as well as between school and the world of work, ensuring that the curriculum is relevant to the demands of the job market and that graduates are employable.

Featuring Anjali Sastry, faculty director of the MIT Jameel World Education Lab, the seminar will showcase the valuable lessons learned from MIT's role in fostering collaboration between academia and industry.

This will be discussed within the framework of a World Bank-funded regional technical and vocational education and training (TVET) initiative, which seeks to enhance partnerships between educational institutions and industry for improved skill development in East Africa.

events.title: Royal College of Music opera: Franz Lehár's 'The merry widow'

collectionItem.title: Royal College of Music opera: Franz Lehár's 'The merry widow'

data.title: Royal College of Music opera: Franz Lehár's 'The merry widow'
data.seoTitle: 2023 Bocelli-Jameel scholars star in 'The merry widow'

heroImage.caption: A woman holds a fan made out of money notes and a handle in the shape of the Eiffel tower.

data.description:
The 2023 Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel scholars Henna Mun and Anastasia Koorn star in Franz Lehár's 'The merry widow' on 11-16 March 2024 at the Royal College of Music (RCM) in London.

Soprano Henna Mun performs as wealthy young widow Hanna Glawari, who is set to remarry to keep her riches within the poverty-stricken Balkan province of Pontevedro. When she encounters her ex, Count Danilo, with his appetite for wine and women, misunderstandings and comedic misadventure abound.

Mezzo-soprano Anastasia Koorn is Praskowia, the wife of Pritschitsch, a retired colonel and the embassy consul for Pontevedro. A proud, formidable woman, she clings to the values of old money, and with her troupe established women looks down on Hanna and attempts to thwart the young widow's romantic affairs.

Henna and Anastasia are 2023 recipients of the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel scholarship at the RCM, which supports their studies at the RCM's world-renowned opera studio. Launched in 2019, the scholarship is awarded to talented musicians chosen both on merit assessed at audition and their need for support to overcome barriers and access world-class training at the college.

events.title: OECD netFWD | One size does not fit all: Strong strategies on flexible financing

collectionItem.title: OECD netFWD | One size does not fit all: Strong strategies on flexible financing

data.title: OECD netFWD | One size does not fit all: Strong strategies on flexible financing
data.address: OECD, Château de la Muette, Paris
data.seoTitle: OECD netFWD annual meeting in Paris
data.description:
In a shift away from financing specific projects, some foundations are providing untied general-support funding to their grantees. Yet flexible funding, which supports the entire work of a grantee and not a specific line of work, remains uncommon.

The 2024 annual meeting of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Network of Foundations Working for Development (netFWD) is convening a panel to discusses how foundations provide a combination of general support and earmarked funding to their grantees, to understand the trade-offs between flexibility and accountability in resource allocation.

This open discussion takes place on 4 March 2024, the first day of the annual OECD netFWD meeting in Paris.
data.seoMetaDescription: The OECD netFWD annual meeting in Paris explores how foundations can provide flexible funding.

data.address: Binny Room, Taj Connemara, Anna Salai, Chennai, India
data.seoTitle: Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Labs - Chennai event
data.description:
Community Jameel and C40 Cities convene government officials, partner representatives and key stakeholders on 28 March 2024 at the Taj Connemara in Chennai, India, for a series of presentations, panel discussions and fireside chats to promote master planning as a tool to accelerate climate action and alleviate poverty.

The Jameel C40 Urban Planning Climate Lab, a collaboration between Community Jameel and C40 Cities, is partnering with the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), the World Bank and the Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority (CMDA) to align city plans with climate goals: to realise greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets, adapt to the impacts of climate change and deliver wider socio-economic and environmental co-benefits through generation and integration of high-quality data to inform evidence-based decision making.
